"The Agents is one of the most brilliant yet simple ideas I've seen in a card game.  It's amazing just how much of a deep game is inside a deck of cards!" Tom Vasel, The Dice Tower
"What makes The Agents such a joy for me is how small it is and yet how very large and complex it feels when playing it. A very interesting and engaging game that grabbed me by the nose and hasn’t let go. Simply excellent. 5/5" Father Geek
"The Agents is a bloody good game. So good that I’ve actually chucked my own money into the Kickstarter campaign. I tell you. Get in on it now if you’re looking for something that looks to take your card gaming in a new direction. You shan’t be disappointed." Little Metal Dog
"The Agents is one of the better games I’ve played this year." Purple Pawn
"A few things about The Agents. One, it’s awesome and you should go back it. Seriously, I really like this game." Board Game Quest
“The Agents is a unique, in-depth card game that will give your brain a workout." Dad's Gaming Addiction
"Highly tense, very action filled... there is a lot to this little card game and a real joy to put it through its paces." Crits Happen
"There's so much strategy in this game - it's ridiculous." Bower's Game Corner
"This game of intrigue and suspense is surprisingly deep and full of tension, but can also be a lot of fun." Perpetual Geek
"The game, from start to finish is a wonderful experience. Saar has something special here." Chevee Dodd
The Agents is a brand new strategic card game that introduces a unique ‘Double-edged cards’ mechanic into the undercover world of covert operations and espionage.
As the Agency shuts down, dismissed and disbanded Agents all around the world are trying to figure out what’s next. Left without a cause, they team up and turn against each other.
You must enlist and lead your own faction of highly skilled professionals into an uncertain territory of betrayal and deception. Show no mercy, reveal no secrets.
The Agents is a deceptively simple card game; easy to learn, set up and start playing, but underpinned by intricate decision-making gameplay. Players must join their Agents into Factions, assign Missions and take their opponents down, to gather intel and win the most points.
Featuring the captivating artwork of collaborator Danny Morison (aka Dark Mechanic), ‘The Agents’ will challenge your imagination and brain power as you plan, plot and scheme your way to victory.
The Agents gameplay is based on a unique, new mechanic we like to call ‘Double-edged Cards’. Each Agent card features a ‘command’ on one end of the card and ‘points’ on the other end. However, the direction in which you place the card will determine from which asset you benefit. If you choose to perform the command, one of your opponents will get the points. If you keep the points for yourself, an opponent gets to perform the command.
Throughout the game, you’ll need both commands and points to advance. Commands will allow you to manipulate Agents, control your Factions, and influence other players. But you’ll need points to buy more Agents and Missions. And ultimately, the player with the most points wins.
Deciding how to place each card will require strategic precision and calculated foresight, as you try to further your own goals, and prevent your opponents from reaching theirs.
Check out the Crits Happen preview of The Agents:
For your support we would like to reward you with exclusive Kickstarter promos, exciting expansion packs and other treats and surprises.
The base-set includes 36 Agent cards, 20 Mission cards and 32 double sided points cards. Additionally, as a Kickstarter exclusive, we are bundling every base-set with 8 Commander promo cards. AND you'll get ALL the unlocked stretch goals (including extra Agents in Base Renovations and additional Missions in Black Ops!)
The Agents was designed to appeal to both casual and hardcore gamers, and as a highly expandable game. Each expansion adds a different depth to the game mechanic and promotes new strategies and player interactions.
For those of you who want to touch and feel The Art of The Agents, we have Danny's incredible illustrations in physical form:

And if you want the PnP in any of our available languages, check this out:
Tiers:
Our stretch goals were designed so that EVERY SINGLE COPY OF THE GAME gets ALL of them for FREE!
Saar Shai (agent "Steel Storm") - Creator of The Agents, Saar is one of those quirky inventor types, who not only has outlandish ideas from his armchair but also gets off his butt and works really hard to make them a reality. From flexible screen interfaces, to ring device controllers, and from game-theory platforms to card games with a twist, Saar's mind comes up with weird and wonderful ideas all centered on making the 'user experience' as fun, rewarding and engaging as possible. With a background in intellectual property and advertising and a day job running a start-up, Saar is now turning his first love - gaming - into his full time passion.
Danny Morison (agent "Dark Mechanic") - Illustrator of The Agents, Danny was brought up on a diet of 80's cartoons, lots of Transformers and also an early fixation with dinosaurs, so he began drawing from a very early age. He loves science fiction and fantasy, and especially how you could create worlds and characters with just your hands and imagination. After leaving university with an Illustration degree under his belt, Danny since worked as a storyboarder, character designer, concept artist, illustrator and poster and flyer designer, but never gave up his initial love of science fiction and fantasy. His style is maybe a bit different to the industry standard but he hopes to one day be able to live off what he loves doing most - creating fantastical worlds, colorful illustrations and drawing really, really big robots!
We're on Kickstarter to raise the funds to produce and publish The Agents. So far, we've invested our own money in the game design, artwork, prototype printing and all other associated costs of getting the game created and tested. But now we need some help! We still need to complete some of the artwork for our expansion packs as well as some of the packaging art. And after that, we need to cover costs of the printing, packaging, shipping, stretch goals, KS exclusives and so on. With your support, we can make it happen!
We want to take a minute to assure you that we are confident that if we meet our target, we will be able to honor our commitment to produce and deliver The Agents. We’ve spent months planning the production of the game, choosing manufacturing and logistics partners and working out the minimum acceptable amount that we need to fulfill our promises to you. Whilst we are aware that Kickstarter, like life itself, comes with no guarantees, we just wanted to let *you* know that *we* know how much trust and goodwill comes with each and every backer’s pledge, and we don’t take that for granted. Thank you for your faith and thank you for your support.

campaign.story:
DEUS EX MACHINA 2 : REBOOT
Deus Ex Machina 2 is the brand new evolution of the cult 1984 Game Of The Year, Deus Ex Machina, the first true multimedia video game ever made.
Written by Mel Croucher, creator of the original game, and published by Automata, the first video games company in the UK, this completely new version is a darkly comic roller-coaster of your whole life. It's a surreal 100-year voyage from cradle to grave, and the music's great too!
DRM free
developed in Unity
play options in English and 18 more languages
soundtrack album released and book prepared for publication
Paypal is now an option to join in and contribute to this project

WE'RE BACK
This is our second Kickstarter campaign, and huge thanks to backers of the first campaign who voted on the cover artwork, music, graphics, and scoring of the game. You have all been rewarded and will have named dedications in our special publication of the book of the game.
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 2 screenshot
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 12 screenshot
WHY YOUR MONEY IS NEEDED
Now we need to put the results of your votes into Deus Ex Machina 2 before we release the PC and Mac versions.
We also need to create the spectacular final sequence of the game itself, to feature as many of your names and faces as we can, alongside our celebrity stars.
We need to produce your lovely rewards too, and of course we must pay Kickstarter their fees for making this all happen.
And OUR GOAL to achieve all of this is to raise £9,800 with your help. That's just under $15,000 or just over €11,000. And if you help us do better than that, here's what we'll do in return ...
STRETCH GOALS beyond £9,800
£12,000
LINUX version. Because we have developed the PC and Mac versions of Deus Ex Machina 2 in Unity, we can produce the Linux version fast and very cost-effectively. Help us hit our first stretch goal to produce the DRM-free Linux version of the game.
£28,000
OCULUS RIFT. We want to make the game as mind-blowing as we can, so a virtual reality version is high on our target list. We'll produce Deus Ex Machina 2 The Director's Cut, for the Oculus Rift virtual reality headset if you can help us hit this stretch goal.
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 16 screenshot
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 14 screenshot
THE GAME
Battle your way to the womb, navigate the birth slalem to get born, then focus, crawl, stand, balance, run, jump, learn, obey and rebel! Pluck the hairs and squeeze the zits of adolescence. Discover the pleasures of love, and the pains of guilt and betrayal. Mess around, run away, hide out, suffer under, heal up, sell off, struggle through, knuckle down, trample over, cave in, dance on! Exploit your power, bust your body, fight your decline, swallow your pills, lose your mind, dream your dreams and fly!
Sperms, cops, killer-ducks, naughty bits, zimmer frames, hallicinogenic eyewear, dead mice, dementia, hermaphrodites, land mines, war crimes, neurons, morons, rock stars, and the greatest voice on the planet as your Narrator.
Imagine if your life was nothing more than an electronic game. Imagine if you knew then what you know now. Imagine if you could replay your little life all over again. Welcome to Deus Ex Machina 2.
Playable demo of Level 1 here: https://bitly.com/1aue61T
Latest trailer here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pm1l2l_xNmA
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 6 screenshot
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 10 screenshot
THE REWARDS
Rewards include the book, the soundtrack album, behind-the-scenes access, and of course the game itself.
Get you hands on original artwork and storyboards from Deus Ex Machina 2
... and collector's artwork and storyboards from the original 1984 game.
WHY KICKSTARTER
Since I founded Automata way back in 1977, we have only ever dealt direct with you, our players. 
We have always listened to what you say and what you want, and we always will. That's why in our previous Kickstarter campaign we gave every backer voting rights on how we create the future of the game.
We have never sold out to banks, advertisers, sponsors or parasites, and we never will. Kickstarter allows us to keep our independence.
We believe Kickstarter is the perfect way for you to join in the fun and choose your ideal rewards.
And we believe Kickstarter is the perfect way for us to reach out to you, our genuine gameplay partners from all over the world.
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 11 screenshot
Deus Ex Machina 2: Level 7 screenshot
OUR SUPERSTAR VOICES
Sir Christopher Lee is The Narrator. The greatest voice on the planet. Star of Dracula, James Bond, Star Wars, Lord Of The Rings and The Hobbit. Become part of his incredible career by joining us on Kickstarter, and gain exclusive access to Christopher Lee interviews, outtakes and behind-the-scenes videos and images.
Ian Dury is The Fertilizer, remixed and remastered from his original brilliant performance. Kickstarter funders can enjoy bonus alternate takes by the legendary star of Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick and Sex And Drugs And Rock'n'Roll.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
All human activity involves risks and challenges, and games development is no exception. Developers can run out of time, producers can run out of money, key personnel can run out the door to join the circus, early ambitions can turn out to be impractical, and there's the situation where everything goes to plan but the plan stinks.

Well, I don't think we're going to run out of time, because all the hard slog has been completed and we're now into perfection phase. I don't think we're going to run out of money, with your help, because the development, the music, the translations and the artwork are all paid for, and this funding is about putting you, the backer, into the game, and about putting the votes of our most loyal Kickstarter backers into practice. And our team is stable, experienced and besides we've already joined the circus.

Since I started the first ever video games company in the UK, my team has never failed to deliver on time every time. This time it's no different and I believe the risk of failing to complete the project is very low indeed. If I happen to drop dead, go mad or disappear, then my colleagues will take over seamlessly.

Essentially, this is the game I have wanted to make since 1983, ever since I ran up against the technical limitations to my future-vision first time round. All I had to do was wait 30 years for the technology to catch up, and for Kickstarter to put me in touch with you. I want to make this game not for myself, but for all of us. So, maybe the only real risk for you to consider is that Deus Ex Machina 2 stinks. 

Right at the start, thirty years ago, I took the risk of defying the norms and busting the templates of conventional gaming, by producing Deus Ex Machina as an interactive movie, played in real time to a perfectly synchronized rock music soundtrack. And now I pledge to do everything I can to turn that original vision into reality at last.

My heartfelt thanks to you for taking the time to read this. If you're considering backing the project then I hope you enjoy the ride and I look forward to welcoming you aboard with open arms. Keep smiling.

Mel Croucher

Update #1 CANDLE's Cover Art!
Candle is a dynamic graphic adventure. It inherits the spirit of classic cinematic adventures like Out of This World or Flashback, and the gameplay mechanics of classic platformer adventures like Abe's Oddysee and Abe's Exoddus, or Heart of Darkness. However, we want it to go one step forward, and so we have brought together all the key features in those games to create a unique title focused on calm puzzle resolution but with a modern and dynamic control over the character.
The main characters of the Atipax tribe: The Wakcha
The most important feature of the gameplay comes from a very specific ability of Teku, the main character: instead of a hand, he carries a candle that can be lit at certain spots, and he must do whatever he can to prevent it from being extinguished. The flame of the candle is key to solving many of the puzzles, as well as uncovering lots of secrets and clues.
But we didn't want the gameplay to drive the entire design of Candle. We love games that have a personal touch, games that do not only deliver a fresh and polished gameplay, but a different and interesting art style. This is why we came up with a risky and difficult idea: to create the entire graphics of the game in a traditional handmade way - not just faking it using the most common digital painting tools.
We paint the entire graphics of the game with watercolors and ink, and then we scan all that stuff in order to build the sprites of the environments, items, menus, etc. Also, the animations of every character and animal in the game are not digital, instead we draw and paint them frame-by-frame, then we scan every single image and build the spritesheets for the animations. Once we have all this working in Unity 4, we set up each level, each scene and each character and so we get a nice handmade look for the visuals. And so, everything lives within the game.
It wasn't easy to achieve this result. We knew since the early development stages that we wanted this to be our own art direction. There are, however, few-to-zero references out there on how to deal with such a process, and that's why we believe that our method can truly give a personal and unique feeling to our games. If there's one feature that we would be glad if people talked about, that's the one.
To support this art style, we are building the narrative in a different and distinctive way. We want it to have mature contents told as a child story, shrouded in innocence and ingenuity. We call it an “adult tale”, and we hope that all of you enjoy this vision.
Candle goes to Wii U!
Also, we have recently been approved as official Wii U developers, so we are designing exclusive features for Candle on that platform. We love Nintendo platforms since our childhood has been full of them, so it was natural for us to go for it. We are already thinking about dedicated gameplay on Wii U - we are not doing any kind of quick port. We will design specific gameplay features for its gamepad: all the menus, inventory and minigames will be tactile-controled on the touchscreen, as well as other unique actions concerning Teku's candle.
And finally, check out a bunch of Candle's OST themes!
Prepare your teeth!
So, what do we have to say in gaming? As an independent studio, we can take certain creative risks that many others can't. Indie games have proved that it is still possible to deliver creative, unique and fresh experiences that can truly be loved throughout the world, despite their minimal budgets. We want to make the kind of games we would love to play. We want the player to feel part of the story, to enjoy not just playing, but experiencing the game in the way the world looks and how the animations play. To sum it up, our goals as an indie team are: art, experimentation and innovative gameplay mechanics. With your help, we can achieve our wildest dreams!
If we meet our initial goal soon enough we may be able to consider some new stretch goals. We would love to localize the game into more languages (for now, we have confirmed the game to be available in both English & Spanish), and of course we would love to add more content to the game such as new worlds, characters and puzzles. Also, the guys at CINEMASENS, who helped us with the pitch video for the campaign, asked us to shoot an exclusive in-depth look at the development. If we could fund it, we would add it as an unlockable making-of video inside the game. If somehow you guys make this the most successful crowdfunding campaign ever we would even consider taking Candle to other platforms (even consoles). You know, the sky is the limit!
If you want Candle to be released on Steam, please help us on Greenlight. We support the Kicking it Forward initiative.
You can also track our game on IndieDB.
Teku Studios is (for now!) a 7-people team. We are Miguel, Jose, Pascu, Elena, Iker, Gelo & Juan Diego. Most of us met some years ago at the University of Zaragoza, and we soon found out that we shared a common passion: we loved videogames. We knew that, one way or another, we needed to do something about it, and so our adventure began.
At first, the "team" was just Jose and Miguel making stuff in their rooms. We started out with very early concepts for our first game (it wasn't even similar to Candle!), and in a few months Elena and Pascu joined the crew to help us make our ideas grow. Then, everything started to change into a more serious, professional game and we even earned some prizes for that very early vision. That's when we decided to go professional: we founded Teku Studios, got ourselves a little studio to work at, licensed Unity 4, and began the full development cycle for Candle (it was Summer 2012).
Again, we worked as hard as we could to make it happen. We coded, painted, animated and debugged 24/7, and invested the prize's money to have the best equipment we could get. Candle grew very quickly and it soon became a very serious game with lots of potential. In early 2013, Juan Diego and Iker read some news about Teku Studios in the local media and reached to us to see if they could help our development. We saw their CV's and got SHOCKED with their experience and credentials, and so they joined the team that very month.
The last member of our crew is Gelo, a writer who met us via a mutual friend and was willing to help us with the English version of the narrator dialogs. Of course, he joined us immediately.
And that's our story (so far). We are a growing indie team, dedicated to our passion and working countless hours without any kind of pay just to see Candle become a full game. And of course, we thank you for your help. With it, we will be able to make this our job for many, many years!
Miguel and Juan Diego are Software Engineers. In fact, they're just the crazy and nerdy side of Teku Studios.
Jose, Elena and Iker have an Arts Degree. They're the triple passion trifecta of Teku Studios.
Gelo is our Wordmaster. When a character needs a voice, we turn to him. He helps us with the campaign as well.
And Pascu... We love Pascu! As the composer, he brings joy and warmth to our hearts in times of need.
If you still wish to know more about us, feel free to visit our website and check out our bios. 100% true stories!

Dear backers,  
From Teku Studios we hope that you have spent unforgettable holidays with your family and friends. We want to wish you all the best this new 2019 and that you can continue enjoying great games!!  
For us, 2018 has been an authentic roller coaster. We started the year with uncertainty… 2017, as you know, was a very hard year for us, having to almost end our adventure as developers. Doing many personal sacrifices, we were able to survive until we could pay the debts that the long development of Candle left behind, having to resign from the office for several months and letting many of our colleagues leave.

Dear backers, it has been a long time since our last update on Kickstarter, and we are aware of all the concerns this may have caused. Our commitment to this project has been absolute from the beginning, and we assure you that this has not changed during these months. We are not going to lie to you: it has been a very hard year for the studio, with many problems both on a personal level as a professional, and that’s why we have not done this update until we were 100% sure that we will comply with everything we say. Fortunately, today the situation is very different, and we bring good news for everyone. There are many questions to answer so... Let’s go!

Dear backers!
The end of the year is near and we wanted to wish you all happy holidays and a happy new year! This will be our first holiday season not developing Candle, and it is still a weird feeling for us. We wanted to thank all of you for your support, and also wish you are enjoying your playtime with Candle so far and all our efforts produced an experience that lives up to your expectations.

In IncrediBrawl, each player guides a colorful cast of characters, from all corners of the imagination, as they meet in an epic clash for glory! Summon the right characters at the right time to outwit your opponents; use whatever strategy you can muster to overcome the randomness of the brawl! Amass the most glory along the way to become the ultimate champion in this crazy contest of luck and wits!
IncrediBrawl is designed to be a fun and chaotic casual card game. What sets it apart from other casual games is its scalable rules framework, called Game Modes. These optional rules allow you to play the way you want, based on your gaming group: from a simplified version perfect for younger children and families all the way to a more complex and strategic game great for more serious gamers.
IncrediBrawl is a card game for 2-4 players. A typical game takes around 30 minutes, and with the various game modes, is perfect for ages 6 and up! 
Want to see all our great characters? Check out the link below!
Each card in IncrediBrawl has a unique ability, which adds interest and strategy into every game. Choosing which character to play and what ability to trigger at just the right time is key to collecting the most Glory and winning the game!
For basic gameplay, players will shuffle their deck and draw 5 cards to start the game. Each player will simultaneously select a character from their hand and play them face down at the current location. After selecting their characters, all players will flip over their cards simultaneously to begin the brawl!
After triggering any abilities revealed by the flip, players then compare their power type and power levels to determine who wins each scrap and the overall brawl. The winner gains one Glory, plus activates any abilities their character may have that trigger off of winning. Each player then discards the played character, and draw one new card before the next round begins. The first player to reach 10 Glory wins the game!

V3G is a brand new game studio, located in Indianapolis, Indiana, but we’re guessing you already knew that if you've watched the video. What you may not know is that we have the capability to uniquely develop for both traditional and digital mediums. How so, you ask? 
We're part of a small interactive agency creating marketing and B2B applications for companies large and small. We enjoy our work, and think we do it pretty well. But we want to grow and expand our capabilities, by creating things for ourselves, not just the next client to walk through the door.
It's also because we have some very talented people working for us that share a singular vision regarding gaming. Our view is that a digital game does not necessarily have to mirror the traditional one. We believe that games should be tailored to embrace and harness the medium in which they are produced. And above all else, our shared desire is to create great games and experiences with friends and family – regardless of where or how you play them.
To learn more about V3G, visit our site: www.vision3games.com
To stay up-to-date on IncrediBrawl, follow us on Facebook or Twitter.
Check out some behind-the-scenes videos on our YouTube channel.
To learn more about our agency side, visit: www.vision3creative.com 
We've chosen Kickstarter over more traditional means of funding because we feel it's perfect for what we're trying to do - break into the game business while finding fans and earning support from the get-go. 
While we believe in IncrediBrawl, and have already invested hundreds and hundreds of hours in development, art and design, we also know that $15k isn't enough to print the game we want to make. We need to know if the gaming public is interested in both IncrediBrawl, and in our unique approach to game development. We've got big ideas for where we can take this hybrid approach to gaming, and we want you to be a part of that! We hope that you will view your involvement as more than just a pledge, and instead consider it an investment in V3G.
From a practical standpoint, we need to know how many copies to print, and get a better idea for what the demand may be like as we bring IncrediBrawl to game stores worldwide. We want to use the highest quality components possible, and add lots of nice "extras" to the base game that will make it stand tall next to any game on your shelf.
While we want this Kickstarter to be super-successful, and hope it will be, we aren't doing this to try and make a huge profit. Anything left over once all the bills are paid will be poured directly back into V3G, to fund development of the digital version of IncrediBrawl, as well as support future traditional game projects.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
While this is the first traditional game project for V3G, it is not the first project we've managed from beginning to end. We're used to handling large projects for clients on a daily basis, with tight budgets and dates that can't be missed, no different than this Kickstarter campaign. Furthermore, because we're an established company already, you don't have to worry about whether or not we'll deliver, or where your Kickstarter funds are really going.

IncrediBrawl is completely designed and illustrated, except for any stretch goal rewards that may be earned during the course of this Kickstarter. Our printer is selected, and ready to begin, as soon as we can get them the files. We have several options for fulfillment and distribution lined up as well, based on the success level of this campaign.

Barring any unforeseen circumstances, our goal is to bring IncrediBrawl to you as quickly as possible. This is currently scheduled for February 2014, but every effort will be made to speed that up if possible.

campaign.story:
This campaign is to produce a very special limited run of a leather-bound hardcover edition that is filled with illustrations and original bonus art from some of today's top conceptual artists and illustrators. Contained therein will be the first volume of the secret history of the end of magic, called Light and Shadow.
The Story
A thousand years ago in the wilds of northern Europe, the necromancer Marduke, Lord of the Sorrian Plateau, was defeated. His monsters were all destroyed, including the dragon ILL, and his fortress of Blackwater Hold was leveled. Marduke’s body was dismembered and burned, and the ashes sent to the four corners of world. The caverns beneath the castle were sealed and buried and all records of the foreign-born sorcerer were stripped from the histories. So it was that Marduke the Death Caller passed from all memory….exactly as he planned.
Light and Shadow is contemporary fantasy that takes place in our familiar, modern world. For a more complete synopsis of Book 1, info of the World of Light and Shadow and the Dragon ILL go here: http://www.lightandshadowbooks.com/
This project can't happen without you.
The story is already complete but in script form. As a filmmaker, I’ve just always written stories in this format without giving it much thought. If I could make the film, great. If not, I could try to sell the script. Although I will no doubt pitch this as a movie as some point, I am really getting into the book as a work of art in and of itself and I am excited to see if there is the support out there for my brand of fantasy fiction.  
If I sell it as is, it could end up as studio slush or worse, it could get made and it would get compromised. Either way, I would be separated from the process with little incentive to work further on the story.
If I go self publish, I won’t be able to do a run of a physical book (especially not what I have planned) and I will have to find some money to get an editor for the finished piece regardless. There is no shortage of poorly edited ebooks out there.  I would end up doing the cover and all the associated artwork myself.  I’m no sloutch on the art front, but I would miss out on the opportunity to work with the great artists that are on board to work on the project. So it's a matter of time, resources and how big a splash I can make with the release....and I need your help.
With funding I will complete the novel of Light and Shadow and do a single run of a leather-bound hardcover edition (numbered) that will look like an ancient tome you just recovered from a dusty library. The book will be filled with Durer engraving-style illustrations depicting various scenes and the interior will all be carefully laid out with decorative borders, chapter markers and icons. The unit price will be high, but if I am going to print something I want it to be cool and serve the story. I will translate this quality down to the ebook which will contain all the bonus art and as much interactivity as we can muster. I'm an old Director multimedia programmer so I'm eager to see what I can go with these tools.
If you've seen a bad science fiction or fantasy movie in the last couple of years and wondered aloud, "Why are these stories so bad?", then you owe it to yourself to at least give me a dollar. 
Plus the book will be full of art by these two, which by itself would be worth the price.
Artists
Nicole Cardiff is a skilled Illustrator and digital painter who will be doing a series of Durer engraving-style illustrations for the book itself.
Nicole Cardiff
Eddie Del Rio is a concept artist who will be doing one to eight concept paintings for the book. His past clients include LucasArts, THQ, Activision, 2K, Lucasfilm, and Walt Disney Imagineering. 
Eddie Del Rio
At the patron level reward you get to take home one of Eddie's original paintings! If I raise enough money he will do a series of eight and all the backers will get digital copies.Here is where the money will go in no particular order:
• Finishing the novel
• Editing, Layout and PrePress
• Ebook authoring and publication
• Durer Engraving Illustrations
• Limited run of Special Edition Hard Cover
• Conceptual Artist (8 tableau paintings)
• Prize Fullfillment (run of pins, Tshirts, posters, etc )
• Website Hosting (press and social outreach)
Rewards
I will be doing limited runs of speciality products just for the campaign including posters, T-shirts, pins and cloaks. If there are enough orders for T-shirts and cloaks and I will have them created locally in Los Angeles and there will be more options for colors, types of printing, and I will open up additional designs in stretch goals.
Thanks for taking the time. If you’d like to know more, please visit the Light and Shadow website here: http://www.lightandshadowbooks.com/

I structured the rewards carefully, but there are some configurations of backers where I could be funded and barely break even, but if the book gets created, I’m OK with that.

Stretch Goals
RED AEGIS Digital Boxed Set: Miscellaneous items like those included in tabletop boxed sets of yore, this collection of bonus goodies contains pregenerated character, encounter charts, maps, and more. The digital boxed also includes two notable exclusives: the RED AEGIS Hacker's Guide and RED AEGIS Unleashed (see descriptions below). Finally, the Digital Boxed Set also grants you access to the Red Aegis Online Tools (character builder, lineage designer, and so on).
RED AEGIS Hacker's Guide: This accessory contains system "hacks" for incorporating RED AEGIS into other game systems. Initial target is the Pathfinder roleplaying game, with additional systems added with stretch goals.
RED AEGIS Unleashed: An epic-sized adventure path that spans 9 time periods (through stretch goals). Each adventure is accompanied by a novelette that ties into the adventure arc. The first module will be penned by Brian R. James and Ed Greenwood.
RED AEGIS Tactics: A tactical skirmish game that is designed for 2-6 players. Players construct an army using everything from axe-wielding barbarians, to spell-slinging archmages--from incredulous biker gang vagabonds, to futuristic space soldiers. This is truly the battle of all ages. Construct your army, deploy to the fields of battle, and defend the prestige of your legacy.
Pyralithos
Join us in designing a tabletop roleplaying experience that you've never seen before!
RED AEGIS is an alternative take on the traditional roleplaying game. This is not just a game about fighting monsters and pillaging ancient ruins for treasure (though we have that too!).
RED AEGIS is an epic, millennia-spanning, strategic roleplaying game where you claim your birthright, rally loyal followers to your cause, and forge a dynasty to stand the test of time.
In RED AEGIS you command successive generations of heroes from the setting's ancient past to the far future–from axe-wielding barbarians to space marines packing gravity hammers, and everything in between.
RED AEGIS is about making difficult choices. These decisions will impact not only your tribe's future, but also the fate of your descendants and the world they inhabit.
We're excited to share with you our vision of epic storytelling. Vorpal Games is devoted to hiring the best talent in the industry to make that vision a reality.
Macuilanx
The Game
In addition to familiar tropes you'd expect from playing a game of Dungeons & Dragons®, RED AEGIS is also infused with millennia-spanning tactical strategy, inspired by games like Sid Meier's Civilization® and X-COM®.
The story of a RED AEGIS campaign is revealed over ten gaming sessions, where you command successive generations of heroes from the world’s ancient past to the far future. 
In RED AEGIS all heroes die. Whether on the field of battle or of old age, your character will eventually die. At the start of each game session you play a new character, a descendant of your starting character’s bloodline.
In RED AEGIS your character abilities are not tied to the individual hero you are playing. Rather, your skills and powers are inherited from and infused with your bloodline, passed from one generation to the next.
LEARN ABOUT GAME PLAY
One of our major motivations with our gameplay experience is to have hundreds, if not thousands, of years pass between each session. Your character in the new session will be a descendant of your past character and will inherent characteristics of the applied dynasty. For example; if in the past your ancestor slayed the great Minotaur lord Kogulous, you would not only gain in-game story-based rewards for such a feat, you would also earn additional Prestige to use in the construction of your descendants in following sessions. Prestige is a value pool that is increased based upon the actions and exploits of your character. One might view this as a type of experience pool, and they wouldn’t be incorrect. Different players would earn at different rates, depending on their actions in the campaign, as well as other factors that we’re not ready to release just yet. In addition, we are implementing a dynamic system by which the storyteller/dungeon master/game master might change from session to session. We refer to this as the Arbiter. The Arbiter will be a role that players will aspire to become, due to the increase in Prestige and other story-based rewards. This process is governed by an element of the game that revolves around the RED AEGIS itself.
Another interesting aspect you may enjoy: as your descendants traverse the timeline your characters will be defined not by equipment (as is in traditional tabletop RPGS), rather by your followers. Followers will have specific skill-sets and professions that will aid your character, and will help define them as your dynasty evolves. This is going to allow for an immense amount of customization, and it’s something we’re eager to show off once completed.
Ikomatshe
The Products
RED AEGIS Player's Guide: An introductory guide to the Red Aegis Roleplaying Game, featuring a complete, learn-as-you-go adventure and a printable character sheet for your custom bloodline.
RED AEGIS RPG Corebook: A lovingly crafted, hardcover sourcebook with high quality maps and illustrations scattered throughout. The book will contain complete rules to build your bloodline, as well as guidance for designing custom monsters and encounters set in the RED AEGIS universe.
Sample Products (Not Final)
The System
The RED AEGIS Roleplaying Game is powered by the LGS (Loremaster Game System™) –a customizable tabletop game engine that supports multiple genres and play-styles.
Unlike most other systems, the LGS encourages the selection of a new game master for each session, allowing for a truly unique experience whereby the actions of the game master are encoded into your shared story!
Hoarthostat
The World
The starting region characters will explore during the game's first age is known to the indigenous tribes as Namarune. This is the cradle of civilization in the Red Aegis setting, and it serves as the region where your tribe will take its formative steps toward building a dynasty and an empire to stand the test of time.
The tribes of Namarune have always feared the world anchors–those crimson, impossibly massive stone monoliths that have stood, inscrutable, since the dawn of time. To approach one was forbidden and taboo. To ignore the omens would be to invite the wrath of the gods down upon yourself and your tribe. 
Yet despite the warnings, each generation witnessed a foolish few that would make a pilgrimage to one the ancient monoliths in defiance of reason and self-preservation. The few that returned, if any, would often ramble of unimaginable wonders and lament of god-like powers wielded ever so briefly. Many of these individuals came to be shunned by their superstitious clan mates and driven into exile, while a rare few would be raised up and heralded as hero-kings. 
During the first arc of the campaign, the player characters gather at one of the fabled monoliths, where they are imbued with fantastic powers and a mandate for greatness.
Which destiny will befall you when heeding the call of the Red Aegis?
Namrune: Age of Monoliths (click image to view map animation)
"No civilization lasts forever, and a society is most treacherous when facing its extinction. Countless inscrutable ruins dot the countryside of Namarune, like ichor-filled sores on a plague-ridden corpse. It’s curious that the most magnificent of these fallen structures often rest within sight of a world anchor—those most holy of stone monuments from which our own civilization was given rise."
Reward Add-Ons
You can add on individual copies of the Red Aegis RPG to any pledge that already is shipping a physical book by manually adding the appropriate amount on the pledge page:
+$15 for each additional softcover Red Aegis Player's Guide. Outside North America, please add an additional $10 shipping per book.
+$70 for each additional hardcover Red Aegis Roleplaying Game sourcebook. Outside North America, please add an additional $30 shipping per book.
+$15 for one (+$25 for two) Red Aegis challenge coin. It's a 1.5" diameter metal coin with colored inlays, numbered serially on the face. Outside North America, please add an additional $5 shipping (for 1 or more coins).
Challenge Coin (Not actual design)
+$30 for each Red Aegis T-shirt. Outside North America, please add an additional $5 shipping per shirt.
T-Shirt design not final
+$60 (limit 1 per backer) for the Namarune: Age of Monoliths map, printed on canvas. Outside North America, please add an additional $15 for shipping.
+$120 (limit 1 per backer) for the Namarune: Age of Monoliths map, printed on canvas and gallery wrapped (stretched over a 1.5" wooden frame suitable for hanging). Outside North America, please add an additional $25 for shipping.
Gallery Wrap Canvas Map (child not included)
Depending on how much funding the project secures, we may add other add-ons at a later date. Ideas we're considering include a RED AEGIS event card deck, pad of character sheets, miniatures, and a leather-bound premium hardcover. If you have any other suggestions, please add them to the comments.
Want to be a Game Designer?
At the start of this Kickstarter we said “Join us in designing a tabletop roleplaying experience that you've never seen before!” and we meant it!
We’re sincere in our desire to solicit feedback from the roleplaying community during every stage of the design. But contributing to online polls and filling out beta surveys only goes so far. For a few of you, that sort of impersonal feedback is not enough. You want to be more directly in contact with the designers and help shape the mechanics or lore of the game.
Backers at the Associate Game Designer level will be given a small section of the Corebook to design. Other RPG Kickstarters may allow you a token task like naming an NPC, or a city, or some such, but this opportunity is much grander than that. Who knows, if you complete your assignment as tasked and on deadline, you may even find additional, paying contracts in your future.
The extra cost associated with this reward level is really for the one-on-one mentoring the backer will have with an established game designer, who will offer advice, critique design work, and so on. There should be no pressure for a backer to turn over a perfect design. Our fantastic editors are here to make every designer’s work shine!
Limited to 20 slots only.
The Design Team
Vorpal Games LLC is devoted to hiring the best talent in tabletop games. The design team for RED AEGIS is highly regarded in the industry, each having designed multiple game sourcebooks for leading publishers, including Wizards of the Coast, Paizo, and Kobold Press.
Brian R. James is an award-winning freelance game designer, co-owner of Vorpal Games, and lead story designer of RED AEGIS RPG. His game design credits include The Grand History of the Realms™, Open Grave: Secrets of the Undead™, Demonomicon™, Monster Vault: Threats to the Nentir Vale™, and Menzoberranzan: City of Intrigue™. Brian also co-authored Giants Revisited for Paizo Publishing. Follow Brian online at twitter.com/brianrjames.
Matt James is an award-winning game designer from Washington, DC, and co-owner of Vorpal Games. He has designed and developed game content for popular publishers such as Wizards of the Coast, Paizo, and Kobold Press. In his spare time he authors short stories and other speculative fiction. Matt is also a disabled combat veteran, having earned the Bronze Star Medal and Purple Heart during his service in Iraq back in 2005. Matt is the lead game developer for the RED AEGIS RPG. Follow Matt online at twitter.com/matt_james_rpg
Ed Greenwood is a Canadian writer and editor who created the Forgotten Realms. He invented the Forgotten Realms as a child, as a fantasy world in which to set the stories he imagined, and later used this world as a campaign setting for his own personal Dungeons & Dragons playing group. He began writing articles about the Forgotten Realms for Dragon magazine beginning in 1979, and he sold the rights to the setting to TSR in 1986. Greenwood has written many more articles and D&D game supplement books for the setting, and he has written Forgotten Realms novels as a freelance author.
Erik Scott de Bie is probably best known for his novels set in the Forgotten Realms setting, including Shadowbane (September 2011) and its sequel, Shadowbane: Eye of Justice (2012). He is also known in the gaming industry, having contributed to such successful Dungeons & Dragons products as Plane Above: Secrets of the Astral Sea™, Shadowfell: Gloomwrought and Beyond™, and the popular Neverwinter Campaign Setting™. Follow Erik online at twitter.com/erikscottdebie
Stephen Radney-MacFarland began working on RPGs in 2000, when he became the RPGA editorial assistant at Wizards of the Coast. Over the years, he's administered the Living Greyhawk campaign, aided in the development of the D&D 3.5 rules, was a developer for D&D 4th Edition, and taught numerous game design classes in the Seattle area. He now works at Paizo as a designer for Pathfinder. His current credits include Advanced Race Guide, Ultimate Campaign, and Mythic Adventures.
Miranda Horner joined the West End Games team as an editor in 1994. Shortly thereafter, she became an editor for the AD&D core team at TSR, Inc., then made the move to Seattle to work with Wizards of the Coast. Since then, she has been an editor on AD&D, Dragonlance, Ravenloft, and D&D (various editions) projects. She also spent some time as a managing producer for several Wizards of the Coast trading card game websites. When she's not spending her working hours wrangling text for D&D and other roleplaying games, she's working on websites for various clients and companies.
Eytan Bernstein is a game designer, editor, and author from New York. He's best known for his work on countless D&D books and articles, as well as contributions to RPG products from numerous other game companies. Eytan is a passionate civil rights activist who champions diversity in gaming. For more information about him, go to http://eytanbernstein.com/.
Mike Schley has close to two decades of experience as a professional artist and designer. His current focus is on providing illustration and cartography services to a wide variety of book and game publishers. He particularly enjoys collaborating with creators of fantasy and science fiction realms such as Wizards of the Coast and Scholastic Books. More of his work and thoughts can be found at www.mikeschley.com
Claudio Pozas is a true dual-threat in the RPG industry with his creative writing ability and amazing artistic proficiencies. Claudio is a writer/artist who has been working with roleplaying games since 2001. His first project of notice was the Counter Collection series for Fiery Dragon Productions. In the past few years, Claudio started working on Dungeons & Dragons for Wizards of the Coast. His writing credits include Heroes of Shadow™ and Heroes of the Feywild™, and his art has been featured in several issues of Dragon and Dungeon magazines. He currently resides in his native Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
Erik Nowak is an advertising graphic designer by day, and a freelance RPG graphic designer by night. (He is quite sure that sleep is for suckers.) Erik has done layout and design work for Goodman Games, Blackdirge Publishing, Dreamscarred Press, Winter Fantasy, The Gamers Syndicate, synDCon, and more. He is especially proud of designing the look for, and laying out, all three glorious issues of the short-lived LEVEL UP magazine by Goodman Games.

updates.update_content:
It’s been a little over a month since the hardcover release of RED AEGIS and it’s been amazing to read the positive feedback the book has received. The game certainly took longer to deliver than anticipated, but now that it’s here and I can hold it in my hands, I couldn’t be more pleased with the results. I cannot thank each of you enough for having made RED AEGIS a reality. The game simply would not exist without your support.
Work on our next project, the RED AEGIS Player’s Guide, is progressing. Author and game designer Erik Scott de Bie has come on board to turn my rough Choose-Your-Own-Adventure style scenario into a compelling branching narrative. Through this introductory story, you’ll play the forbearer of your tribe and learn of the harrowing events that led to the Awakening and first contact with a world anchor. This slice of interactive fiction will be included in the Player’s Guide, but I’m also considering releasing it online as part of the RED AEGIS Digital Tools. More on that possibility in a future update.

I have received word from Print Ninja that the shipping container with RED AEGIS has cleared customs at the Port of Los Angeles and will arrive by the end of the week!
Confirm Mailing Address
If you ordered a hardcover game manual, it is very important that you confirm your mailing address is current and accurate at Backerkit. To do so, navigate to , enter your Kickstarter email address into the field and press the “Get My Survey” button. You will then receive a survey link through email where you can examine your mailing address. I plan on mailing out the first wave of books the weekend after next, so please double check your address as soon as possible.
PLAY

Hardcover

The good news is that the RED AEGIS Roleplaying Game is at the printer! The bad news is that they only just received the print-ready files from us last Thursday. That puts us in the digital proofing stage, where they apply our documents to their print templates and we sign off on the master proof.
RED AEGIS on DriveThruRPG

It’s nearly June!? Ye gods, where did the time go?
RED AEGIS Core Rulebook
This month saw additional polishing to the Core Rulebook in preparation for its public debut. Alas, I didn’t get the corrections to our layout designer in time for this month’s update. That work should be completed within a week, however, and will be automatically applied to your library at . An email will be sent out at the time of the update.

Chapter 11—the last chapter to need significant edits—is now complete and in layout. Thank the gods!

I still need a few weeks to add the side-column annotations I spoke of in a previous update, but backers should expect to download the complete RED AEGIS Core Rulebook from DriveThruRPG.com by the end of April. Pinky promise. 
If you have an existing account at DriveThruRPG.com, but your email there differs from your Kickstarter email, please be sure to provide your DriveThruRPG email in the appropriate survey question at BackerKit. If you don’t already have a account, no problem. The email you receive from DriveThruRPG will contain a link to download your free copy of the sourcebook.

Quick update this month folks.  
I have uploaded a copy of the oh-so-nearly-complete manuscript to BackerKit for your review (Corebook Preview - Feb 2016). Sadly, illness prevented me from finishing the remaining edits in their entirety. Delays are annoying, no question there, but in this 320 page document I hope you see the game you pledged your support towards all those many months ago.

This project is the 12th installment of my ongoing series of projects to re-visit or re-create artwork from early tabletop role-playing games.
Last time I returned to M.A.R. Barker's classic Empire of the Petal Throne RPG, I created new illustrations for the inimical nonhuman races from that game - and I also created seven brand new drawings of sea creatures who didn't get 'em in the original EPT rulebook.
This time, I'm creating new illustrations for the 12 unique land creatures:
Chlén (the Armour-Beast)
Chnélh (the Ape-Mutant)
Dnélu (the Concealed Leaper)
Dzór (the Forest Giant)
Feshénga (the Many-Legged Serpent)
Hyayú'u (the Whooper)
Kurukú (the Small Giggler)
Mnór (the Shaggy Insect Creature)
Rényu (the Loyal Follower)
Sérudla (the Pale Murderer)
Tsi'íl (the Giant Herbivore)
Zrné (the Barbed One)
Few of them received illustrations In the original Empire of the Petal Throne RPG rulebook. Which is a tragedy, because EPT creatures are awesomely cool! Here's an example, the inimical nonhuman Hluss from one of my previous projects:
Click here to visit my DeviantArt page, where you can see lots more of my Tékumel® art!
BONUS! EVERY backer will receive a PDF copy of my new 4 to 8 page systemless Tekumel adventure: "The Circle of Columns" - based Professor Barker's Northwest Frontier Gazeteer (hex 4407) - in addition to their other backer rewards.
I love Tékumel! Empire of the Petal Throne was one of the first tabletop RPGs I ever owned or played, and Tékumel is still by far my favorite role-playing setting. I recently announced plans to publish my own Tékumel-based RPG with Béthorm: The Plane of Tékumel. The Tékumel artwork created in these projects will appear in Béthorm. If you want to try gaming on Tékumel right away, lots of material is available online to help get you started!
Listen to an interview including a discussion of my efforts to re-create my lost TSR art here. All of the new artwork from these projects is posted to my DeviantArt page (jeffdee.deviantart.com) as it's completed, so you can see how they turned out.
STRETCH GOALS!
Every set of twelve postcard prints - and every set of twelve signed 8 1/2" x 11" prints - will ALSO include prints of my brand new drawings of these friendly nonhuman races when backing reaches the following levels:

$3380: Pé Chói (the Listeners)

The Tékumel Foundation has graciously offered to make some of Professor Barker's previously unpublished drawings available to me for reference. Which is freakin' awesome. Here's an example, showing a side-by-side comparison of a quick pencil sketch of a 'Hrá' (aka Bloodsucker) by Professor Barker, and my own interpretation of the creature based upon his:
Where possible, I've included links to renditions of these creatures by later artists. Brett Slocum's GURPS Tékumel Conversion site also provides short text descriptions of all of these creatures and more.
This project is dedicated to Victor Raymond of the Tékumel Foundation, for all his encouragement and support!

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This project essentially follows the same model as my previous Tekumel art projects. Once again I'm (1) creating new drawings of creatures from Empire of the Petal Throne, some of which have never been depicted in published worked before, and (2) I'm relying on the Tekumel Foundation for access to previously unpublished visual reference for some of the stretch goals.

#1 poses no difficulty. I've drawn pictures throughout my professional career.

#2 could be an issue if the Tekumel Foundation isn't responsive to my requests, though this wasn't a problem during my previous Tekumel art projects. Furthermore, many of the creatures have been depicted by artists other than Professor Barker in official Tekumel products other than the original EPT over the years, and I can turn to those for visual reference if need be.

In addition to those issues, I recently went through a period where I'd fallen behind on delivering backer rewards. I've been working hard to get back on track, and I foresee no difficulties in delivering the backer rewards for this project in September.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi again, and thank you for backing my Beasts of Tsolyanu Kickstarter project.
Kickstarter was an excellent fit for my projects to draw all of M.A.R. Barker's Tekumel creatures. But now that that's been accomplished, I've moved into a phase where I need to produce a steady stream of smaller numbers of pieces for all sorts of different projects. And Kickstarter just isn't the right place for that.
So: I'm switching over to Patreon, at least for now, which will allow me to fund pieces individually (rather than in big blocks), and enable fans like you to support me in that effort at whatever level you choose.

Thanks for your support!
Tékumel was the first complete tabletop role-playing game setting ever published, in TSR's 1975 "Empire of the Petal Throne".
My next Kickstarter project - "Béthorm: the Plane of Tékumel" - revives the Tékumel setting in a lavishly illustrated new RPG! Raise high your swords for the glory of the Empire, and march to battle against the Enemies of Man!

Men have conquered the inner planets of the Solar System and are now travelling through the Ether. They discovered the ancient culture of the Martians and the misty wilderness of Venus. Mercury is a world of extremes but rich in valuable raw materials. The Asteroid Belt and the Earth’s moon, Luna, are waiting for further exploration. And there is still a lot to discover on Earth itself.
Under the burning sun of the Martian steppes, the steamy mists of the Venusian jungle, the deadly cold of the Dry Ice Zone on Mercury, or at the banks of the Amazon River on good old Earth – the world of Space: 1889 is full of adventures.
Everything Jules Verne could have written.
Everything H.G. Wells should have written.
Everything A. Conan Doyle thought of but never published because it was too fantastic.
Everything you need for the adventures of the century.
Almost 25 years ago, well known game designer and author Frank Chadwick came up with the idea of a roleplaying game set in a world inspired by the fantastic novels of early Science Fiction authors like Jules Verne or H. G. Wells.
Space: 1889 was first published in 1988 by Game Designers Workshop, followed by several additional products, amongst them supplements like “Ironclads and Ether flyers,” adventures like “Canalpriests of Mars,” or board games like “Temple of the Beastmen.”
GDW is long gone but, nevertheless, the fan-base has hung on to this “roleplaying game in a more civilized time” and with the growing popularity of 'steampunk culture' the time has never been better to reintroduce a new edition of the game for old and new fans alike.
The Space: 1889 Crowdfunding project is a cooperation between Uhrwerk Verlag/Clockwork Publishing, Chronicle City, and the master himself, Frank Chadwick.
We have several very cool stretchgoals planned and we will update this section as the project progresses.

Risks and challenges
Clockwork Publishing / Uhrwerk Verlag has been printing RPG books since 2009 on a monthly basis, with now more than 50 titles in print, so we basically do know what we are doing. Plus - with Chronicle City we have a partner, who knows the business of selling books internationally outside of Germany.

Since the German rulebook is already out, we “only” have to translate and edit the texts of it to English (a process, which is already in process, and should be finished shortly for the main rulebook). Also the art is already done.
Both doesn’t count for all of the additional stuff the stretchgoals might bring upon us, but we have enough capable writers and artists to meet the deadlines we set ourselves here.

International shipping: we will work together with an experienced US-based forwarder, who will handle the shipping within the US for us. For Europe and the rest of the world we will handle that by ourselves. But since we are already selling books on a quite regular basis, we shouldn’t encounter too many difficulties there.

Of course, the best laid plans sometimes go astray, but as two experienced companies in the rpg industry, we should be able to sail around any cliffs that might appear on our way.

campaign.story:
Cellar Map in Grid Squares
We started making maps years ago for our own roleplaying purposes. Our objective was to create maps that were fine to look at and re-arrangable, so that we could get the maximum use out of each piece of paper.
It was easy to find high quality maps, but they were expensive, and were often too specific and could only be used in certain situations. We wanted a great, standard set of maps that covered the stereotypes; typical situations we found ourselves in repeatedly, such as an ambush along a road, crossing a bridge, traveling through a cave, etc.
Our Maps
We created a series of full color, high quality, 11x17 maps that are designed to fit together (typically in pairs) and that are specifically engineered to be rotated and rearranged, creating alternate layouts. Using this technique, you can cater to most types of encounters a party will face in a typical fantasy roleplaying game with fewer total maps scattered about your table. Let me give you an example:
Here are two 'cellar' maps:
and
When you put the maps together, you get a winding layout with many entrances and exits. This is good for chases and sneaking around.
but if you reverse the pages, you now create a layout that is open and spacious; which is better for a large battle.
In addition, these maps have doors that are placed at a common distance from the edge, so that many maps (even if they were not designed specifically to line up) will fit together and allow your party to move between them seamlessly.
New Textures
We've recently begun using hand-drawn and higher resolution textures. We're toying with a lot of possibilities, but here are some quick results:
Wine Cellar Old/New Comparison 1
Wine Cellar Old/New Comparison 2
Here are 3 "Dungeon" Tiles:
Dungeon Entrance
Dungeon Center
Dungeon BossRoom
We've named these "Dungeon Entrance, Center and Boss Room". Typically, players will start in the lit staircase in the entrance, and from here they have a wide variety of directions they can go. The center allows players a large open space to battle, with lots of high and low ground and coverage points, and the boss room is a big open area where players can engage a big enemy. We chose not to make a simple "tile" system where everything has gobs of doorways. Completely pre-constructed layouts have no versatility. A tile system has so much versatility that everything looks stupid, and none of the situations are ever all that tactical.
Our system does everything - Various entry and exit points that are set to standard positions. You can tile them, but every "pairing" was specifically crafted to offer something useful, that the players may actually want - The typical case with these 3 rooms would be to simply line them up! Using a marker or object to block the top middle path, the players have a large winding battle over a lot of ground with crooks, shadows, lots of interesting elevation, ledges they can jump down (or up, if they are skilled) with pillars to crouch behind, all leading up to a boss fight.
However, note the versatility, and how each layout actually offers you a scenario where something interesting is occuring:
Dungeon Layouts
And this is with only THREE maps. Add more maps, some flats and hallways, and you're sure to be able to place a few pieces down and have a great battle.
So you can see how maps can be reversed, rotated and rearranged. Once more tiles are completed, you'll be able to make much larger battles, and your maps will have more diversity. But even if you just choose 2 random maps, you'll have an ideal Battle Map.
What we believe is that 99% of players will be using 2 maps at a time, for a total 22"x34" battle space. A larger area does not appeal to them because they either cannot fit it on their table, or so much of that space isn't being used in the battle to be irrelevant. With this system, you CAN make bigger battles, but it is specifically focused on these 2-map scenarios where your players have an objective. Once you complete that objective "reach the boss room door" players will usually re-situate their map anyway. Or in many cases, they are only playing out the key battle in the dungeon, not sprawling a giant map for the entire dungeon when no combat even occurred. For each major scene, you can select exactly what you want and set parameters.
Print Quality and Durability
These maps are printed on heavy cardstock and then UV coated, creating a very nice and durable map that is partially resistant to spills. If you spill on a normal flimsy map, it can be completely destroyed. With these maps, the edges might still be damaged, but your map will often survive.
Additionally, for an Add-On cost, you can have all of your maps Laminated. This with further protect them and even allow you to write on them with some dry/wet erase markers. Since all markers are slightly different, make sure you test your markers in a small corner of the map beforehand.
What Will You Get?
If you pledge at the basic level, you will get a 12-page map pack, filled with classic maps that every adventuring party needs. Most of these will be interchangeable maps. There are also some bonus maps unlocked with rewards.

If you pledge at the expanded level, we will throw in many more maps. They will all have the same high quality and standards, but these maps are less common in adventures. If you pledge at the $200.00 level, you will become an Arcknight Insider. For starters, you will get the Expanded Map Pack, with Double-Sided Maps and Laminated if you wish, as well as a sneak peak at all of our upcoming Arcknight products. Next, we'll send you a fully playable prototype version of our upcoming Tactics / Roleplaying Boardgame, Dungeon Rumble. Lastly, Arcknight's Lead Designer and Art Director will work directly with you and CREATE YOUR OWN MAP. That's right, any map you want, we'll work together to design and build it, right over skype / chat / text / email, anything you want.
You suggest it, and we'll go through the preliminary design stages together, and bring it to life. As we develop the map, you'll get progress reports, and when it's finished you'll receive a limited edition and signed version of your suggested map. If you're looking for something a little more specific for an upcoming adventure, or haven't been able to find a certain type of map, we'll make it for you! There's only one exception, the map needs to be general purpose enough that other players could make use of it in their games as well. Perhaps you'd like a graveyard, a barracks, an office for a chancellor, or a king's throne room? You've got it. From here, every Expanded Map Pack will include a copy of your map as an additional bonus, along with a custom thank you and acknowledgement of your support. We've limited this option for now, because we're worried if we have many takers, we just wont be able to make our timeline goals. This isn't an "eventually" kickstarter project. If we're funded, we'll complete these alterations and new maps quickly, and get them to you within several months.
Add-Ons
You're going to get a LOT with the extended Map Pack. As an example, the Cellar, Jail, and generic 'Dungeon' maps will all interconnect, so you can make some large fields. That being said, there will always be people with custom desires.
Without complicating Kickstarter or making a long list of irritating Backer Tiers, I'd like to instead offer some Add-On options. Add these amounts to your Pledge, and you'll be able to identify what extras you'd like when the survey's go out after the kickstarter completes.
Upgrade A Map Bundle to be Double Sided (Duplex) - We've reached our $10k Goal! This means every backer will receive their Pre-Set maps double sided (this includes the Colosseum, Tavern, Highland Home, etc.) If you would like the rest of your reversible, normal maps to be double-sided with alternate options on the back as well: such as the Dungeon, Forest Road, Cellar, and Cave maps, add +$10.00 to your Pledge for the Basic Map Pack, and +$15.00 to your Pledge for the Extended Map Pack. Since the Extended Map Pack has many Pre-Set Maps, this add-on is discounted for the Extended Map Pack accordingly. Other rewards, such as the Backer Goals that grant you bonus maps, will be double-sided as well if you've upgraded your Map Bundle for double-sided maps.
Instead of B-sides, you may instead choose to have Grid Squares on the front of your maps, and Hexes on the back of your maps, if you upgrade to double-sided maps.
Laminate all of your Maps - For $10.00 we will laminate every map in your order (Add only $5.00 for the Standard Map Pack). Lamination will further protect our maps, and with high quality dry/wet erase markers you can draw directly on the maps. (Since all markers are different, make sure to test your markers in a small corner of your map.)
Add Additional Specific Maps - For every +$3.00 you add to your pledge, you can specifically pick any 2 additional 11x17 map pages to be included in your bundle. Remember that most maps are designed in pairs (+$1.50 a map page). We can do this any number of times to save shipping, so long as your Maps fit in the USPS package. If they do not fit, we will contact you and inform you of your options.
Stretch Goal - $5000 - ACCOMPLISHED!
We've reached our first Stretch goal of $5000! All backers will had an additional 2-page Pre-Set Map of a Bandit Fortress thrown into their order. This map will be a classic fort that players may assault or defend, with towers, walls and the great style you expect of all our Arcknight Maps.
Stretch Goal - $10000 - ACCOMPLISHED!
We've reached $10k! We're throwing in 2 extra pages of Dungeon Maps (A straight hallway and a curved hallway with adjoining rooms) in the same tile-set as our other Dungeon Maps, so you can build even larger dungeons and have more options. Additionally, everyone's Pre-Set maps will be printed double sided. Pre-Set maps include the Colosseum, Bandit Fortress, Manor, Highland Home, etc. The A-side of these pieces will be the standard Pre-Set map, while the B-side of each piece will offer alternate layouts, and additional landmarks to be interchanged with the map. For instance, Coliseum B-sides may contain fallen pillars and destroyed walls, providing alternate routes with rocky terrain. The Manor B-sides might convert the 2-story thin Manor into a wider single story, with additional quarters, and a stable. And the Bandit Fortress B-sides could provide additional ways in or out of the keep undetected. These are just suggestions, but you can count on us to be forthcoming with our process as we design these maps, and keep with the same high quality and versatility we've shown in all our maps.
Instead of B-sides, you may instead choose to have Grid Squares on the front of your maps, and Hexes on the back of your maps, if you upgrade to double-sided maps.
Stretch Goal - $15000 - No Longer Available.
We've abandoned our $15,000 stretch goal. Instead, all backers will be given a 2-Page Pre-Set Graveyard as a special thanks, whether we make 15k or not as an apology.
New Backer Goals
ACCOMPLISHED!! We reached 100 Likes for Arcknight on Facebook. All of our backers will receive an extra 2 pages of Forest Maps. Extra maps means extra options when it comes to normal encounters on forests and along roads. These may not be the most glamorous, but in our experience they're among the most used maps in every campaign!
At 300 Likes for Arcknight on Facebook every Backer will receive an additional 2 pages of Maps in the Dungeon Tileset as well. These maps are designed to fit with the current Cellar, Dungeon, and Jail maps, and will connect with any future Dungeon and Laboratory maps as well.

Why Kickstarter?
We have a handful of older maps without lighting, texturing and effects. They are decent enough for amateur purposes, but are not a professionally finished product. Finishing these maps and creating entirely new ones is a time consuming process, and we will tackle this based on the feedback we get from you, the backers. Apart from restyling a few older maps, our new maps will be rotatable and interchangeable. This concept has been a smashing success, and we will be keeping this idea going forward with our new maps.
What do you mean by Lighting and Texturing?
Let me show you. Here is a standard version of the cellar map from above, without custom lighting and effects:
As you can see, it's just not that interesting. It doesn't come alive or illicit any mood or impact.
Here is another example of an early ship map with little custom lighting and editing:
and here's a similar ship with custom lighting and effects:
Say what you will about the difference in layout, but the second ship is vivid and compelling, and if this kickstarter is successfully funded we'll be bringing all of our maps to life in this way, printing them in large batches, and delivering them to your doorstep.
Show Us More
Gladly.
Highland Home
Colosseum
Here is an example of an unfinished 'Crypt' style map, and how it can be tiled. Throw in a few signature rooms, like a tomb, and you've really got something!
2 - Page Crypt
4 - Page Crypt
6-Page Crypt
Here are a number of older maps that have not been reworked yet. These will give you an understanding of what you will get if you back this project. These maps, and more, will be redrawn with dynamic lighting, glows and effects. In addition, their layout and format will be altered where possible to become modular, rotatable and interchangeable (if they weren't already, although as you can see many of them were.)

Grid Square or Hexes, at your request.
Frankly, hexes are superior in most ways. For our own purposes, we convert all maps to Hex, and convert all games that use grid into hexes with house rules. That's why you'll see most of these maps with Hex instead of Grid Squares. However, we also understand there are some major reasons why people use Grid squares: There's a nostalgic factor, some people simply prefer it, and more importantly, some games have adopted the Grid Square as their official standard, and converting the rules can be annoying.
If you back our kickstarter, we will print your maps in either Hex or Grid Squares at your request. After the kickstarter is successfully backed, we'll send you a survey, and you can tell us what you'd like. We can also print them gridless, for use with transparent overlays.
Just let us know what you need, and we'll do our best.
We can also print the grid at custom sizes upon request.
What size are your Grids?
Both grid and hexes are just about 1" in size. Hexes are 1" from edge to edge, and ~1.1 inches tip to tip. The full hex area of our (2x) 11x17 maps is 20x22 hexes. This size fits most miniatures. Here is a cellphone picture taken during a game:
The miniatures we use are from various sources, and they all fit nicely. 
We can also print the grid at custom sizes upon request.
Also, don't forget to Like us on Facebook:  Arcknight or search for Arcknight.

updates.update_userinfo: Ugly Truths - Lets talk about laminate
updates.update_content:
James Crisp sent me a very nice message, and asked a difficult question - 

Q - "You mentioned switching to a new laminate part way through fulfillment. On the next project you mentioned a get everything new pledge. If we get that level will we be able to get the matching laminate or will they be in the new style glossy laminate?"
You guys may have noticed in your dealings with us here at Arcknight that I'm doing the legitimate thing on kickstarter and addressing conflicts and setbacks. I don't believe there's a reason not to be open with all of you, and I certainly don't wish to feel like I'm hiding anything.

Here is my response, and i would like to share it for everyone : 

"It's possible we could buy another batch of the anti-glare laminate, but I don't think that venture was ultimately successful. As we move along, we keep adjusting things, and we've discussed (especially from your point of view - as a backer who jumped aboard early on and are our best supporters) 'what can we realistically do?' And there aren't great choices in that matter. Across the board we've decided to gracefully just make the improvements we can make as we go, continue making the best possible product, and over time (probably every generation of maps you get) you'll see improvements in what we're doing and how we're doing it.

updates.update_userinfo: So when's the next map kickstarter? What's new? Why do I care?
updates.update_content:
I've been brainstorming what to 'say' in our next map kickstarter. I assumed I'd say something cheeky like "when you have great maps and everybody loves them, what do you do to improve them? …. nothing. You just make a bunch more."

And then we started making the 8-page retail map pack for the 'City Streets'. Keep in mind, one of the tier options for the new kickstarter will be pitched specifically to our current kickstarter backers, a tier that will give "everything we've made that you didn't get from the first kickstarter". Specifically, this means if you back the next kickstarter, you'll get any of the missing pages from these new retail packs.

These new city streets pages have 'slums' and tighter groupings of buildings, and large key buildings, and a bunch of different alleyways for different types of encounters… and we decided to try some retexturing and rework the ground, along with a few philosophical changes in the layouts - these have narrow alleys you can clearly fit down. Sometimes wide alleys you may even be able to get around enemies in. Then there's very thin gaps between buildings we've visually made so it's really a GM's call whether you can squeeze through. We removed the 1 hex 'gap' on the edge of a number of maps, so you can push buildings up against each other, or pair them with a map that has a gap for a small alley, or pair 2 gaps for a wide alley. The choices are much more complex now.
Aside from that, I always felt the City Streets were fantastic, but just a little "stiff". So we started tweaking at the look. I guess I just better show you :
